item.description:
Report X-2024110019

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-01
  • City: WILLINGTON
  • State: CT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AN UNDECLARE PACKAGE WAS FOUND WET DUE TO INTERNAL LEAKAGE AND HAD NO DOT LABELS ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE PACKAGE. 1X1 FLUID GALLON REGULATED METAL CAN OF RUSTOLEUM HEAT RESISTANT COATING METAL SOLVENT ALUMINUM COVER SEAL FAILED AND THE COVER BECAME LOOSE AND THE CONTENTS LEAKED OUT STAINING THE WHOLE CAN AN INVOICE WAS INCLUDED THAT STATED ITEM #36ND74 RUSTOLEUM HEAT RESISTANT COATING METAL SOLVENT ALUMINUM WAS ENCLOSED. THE PACKAGE CONTAINS REGULATED ITEMS INSIDE OF THE PACKAGE WITH NO DOT LABEL ON THE OUTSIDE OF THE PACKAGE MAKING THE PACKAGE UNDECLARED.

Picture 5: inner packaging. 2 x 2L plastic bags of Ecolab 6100659 Maxx Dual Action Floor Cleaner - Bright Speed. Packing slip states UN2491, Ethanolamine solutions, 8, III, CORROSIVE.

item.title: Report E-2024110000
item.description:
Report E-2024110000

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-31
  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LDA experienced a UN2051 Nalco 1606A release from (3) 275-gallon poly totes. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct onsite cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 8 ounces of product released from the caps of all three totes. The caps on the totes were loose, resulting in material sloshing out in transit. The material impacted the tops of the totes and a 3” x 3” area of plywood in the trailer. The caps were tightened, and a slosh test was conducted on the totes to ensure there would not be further release. The impacted plywood, pads, and PPE were then containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UPW experienced a UN3149 Minncare HD Disinfectant release from a box containing (4) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 4’ x 4’ area of the concrete dock floor and pallet wood due to a forklift puncture. The impacted area was cleaned with absorbents. The damaged jug, impacted absorbents, PPE, and cardboard were placed into one 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted pallet wood, absorbents, and cardboard were placed into a second 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On October 25, 2024, one (1) half-gallon (0.5) pail of nitric acid was damaged in transit and released approximately one-half gallon (0.5) of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel utilized hand tools, absorbents, and soda ash to remediate the nitric acid-impacted impacted pallet, cardboard boxes, and trailer floor. One (1) damaged jug of nitric acid was containerized into one (1) 5-gallon pail and labeled as hazardous. All impacted debris, spent absorbents, and PPE were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LTU experienced a UN2735 Evercat ZR-70 release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.25 cup of product released to a 1’ x 6” area of the concrete dock floor and tote body due to a crack on the lid of the tote. The material was transferred from the damaged tote to a new one. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents used to clean the spill into (4) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024100739
item.description:
Report E-2024100739

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-04T12:23:29+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-24
  • City: PHILADELPHIA
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During a routine inspection at Veolia's ten day in-transit facility in Philadelphia, PA, Veolia staff discovered a compromised container. Upon investigation, they found that inner packages had leaked through three outer containers and were generating heat through a chemical reaction with the absorbent material present. It was determined that 5 x 1 gallon inner packages in each of the three containers were not upright and had leaked through vented caps onto an absorbent. It was further determined the absorbent utilized by the shipper contained organic material which resulted in the reaction and heat generation. The material was repackaged with all inner packages up right and placed in individual plastic bags with inorganic cushioning and absorbent to prevent any reaction resulting in three 55 gallon drums and one 30 gallon drum. The original absorbent material was wetted, placed into containers and transported for disposal along with the repackaged packages.

  • Description: It was reported that 495-gallons of gasoline was released impacting a impervious surface of approximately 150’-by-150’, and nearby storm drains that outfall to the onsite retention pond. All the manways and retention pond were checked to verify no fuel had left the property. E3OMI pumped all of the liquid from the storm drains and basin. 21,840-gallons of gasoline impacted water was recovered and processed for recycling.

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-06
  • City: JEANNETTE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNIVAR SOLUTIONS USA INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver noticed product leaking as he was taking a break and notified supervision. The leak was coming from the crash/spill box area. The driver began to drive the equipment and was instructed by supervision to stop driving the equipment and pull into a safe area. The driver stopped and the local municipality's fire department and EHS arrived at the scene, as well as, a third party environmental clean-up company, McCutcheon's. The HCL was off-loaded into 10 totes, which were loaded into straight truck with a lift gate, approximately 1,600gallons were off-loaded into another Univar tanker and taken to the Univar Altoona plant, and the remaining product remained in the original tanker. The 10 totes and original tanker were taken to the Univar Solutions Bunola plant. Approximately 20 gallons of HCL was released. Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection conducted a site visit and provided a satisfactory rating for the response and clean up. PADEP #1410124

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XFK experienced a UN1866 AlphaGuard Puma Quick Flash release from a 2-gallon metal pail. XPO terminal personnel conducted cleanup prior to ERTS notification. XPO advised one cup of product released to the trailer floor. The damaged pail and wood chips used to clean the material were placed together in a poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to properly containerize the waste and separate the product from the wood chips. Contractors arrived onsite and separated the damaged pail from the wood chips. The damaged pail appeared to be punctured by a forklift blade and was containerized into a 30-gallon metal drum. The impacted wood chips were placed into a 55-gallon metal drum and submerged as a precaution due to the low flash point of the material. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XDM experienced a UN2693 Sodium Bisulfite Solution 40% FG release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released to a 5’ x 7’ area of the trailer floor. The tote was cracked on the tote corner due to improper loading. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a two new ones. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized. The impacted area was cleaned with absorbent. All impacted absorbents and tote pieces were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UVG experienced a UN1789 Aqua Balance Muriatic Acid release from a box containing (4) 1- gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 15 ounces of product released to a 4’ x 4’ area of the pallet and a 1.5’ x 1’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. The impacted areas were cleaned with absorbents and sodium bicarbonate to clean and neutralize the material. The damaged jug and 3 other impacted jugs in the box were loose packed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The impacted cardboard, absorbents, pads, and PPE were placed into a second 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding a leaking cap on a poly tote containing hazardous product, GL 120D. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimated 0.5-cup release onto a the top and side of the tote. The contractor used absorbent pads to clean the release and was able to tighten the loose cap on the tote. One 55- gallon DF containing neutralized impacted absorbents pads and PPE was containerized for waste disposal. XPO will manage all waste generated from the spill response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

item.title: Report E-2024100703
item.description:
Report E-2024100703

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-31T09:22:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-15
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 15, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon jug of UN1789 was crushed during unloading and released approximately six (6) ounces of product to the dock floor and cardboard box. R+L personnel utilized a fire extinguisher when they noticed smoke emerging from the box. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel discovered that all released Transchem Muriatic Acid (UN1789) had dried, on the impacted surfaces, due to the fire extinguisher being utilized by R+L personnel. Crews collected the damaged jug and the impacted cardboard box for disposal. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and swept them in with hand tools. All waste was containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On October 14, 2024, four (4) one-gallon jugs of paint were damaged and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior and contents of the trailer. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Coastal Environmental Solutions (COENS) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the impacted shrink wrap, and impacted cardboard boxes the product was contained in, for disposal. COENS personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas, and worked them in with hand tools. Crews restacked the undamaged freight for normal transport. All paint (UN1263) impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum, two (2) 30-gallon drums, and one (1) 15-gallon drum.

  • City: BLYTHE

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0616 XPO contacted the call center to report a spill in Blythe CA. XPO advised that due to a container failure 1 gallon of Cling No. 153 was released into the trailer floor from a 55-gallon metal drum. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 cups of Cling No. 153 released due to the drum lid being defective. The contractors neutralized floor & trailer with Sodium Bicarbonate and overpacked drum to (1) 95-gallon metal drum, neutralized pallet to (1) 55-gallon metal drum, impacted and neutralized PPE and absorbents to (1) 30- gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: LOUISVILLE

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 525887
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver approached light at intersection of Old Henry Road and Terra Crossing Blvd. Driver had come to the light and almost stopped when the light turned green. The driver continued to tum left in the outside lane. As he was in the turn, the load took over and he overturned. When the fire dept and hazmat team arrived, they began with pads and oil dry. When the trailer was up righted on 729 gallons remained in compartment 3. Emergency response crews began with GRA-KA T arriving first. They enlisted the help of PECCO and Early Environmental. Later that night, PECCO was to take lead of the remediation and clean-up project. The following day, Shield Environmental was called in to geoprobe the site as well as private property. Lewis Personnel on site - Timothy Jennings and Raymond Boggs LMPD-Officer Koester Anchorage Middletown Fire Department/HazMat Team - Major Oser Battalion Chief Erica O'Brien, Environmental Specialist Sarah Hettel - KY State EPA Matt Vanderpool - Health Dept & Haz Mat Team Tracie Murphy - Spill Center

  • Description: When driver went to leave the facility after being loaded he noticed liquid dripping from the trailer. This facility has an emergency response team located on sight and they put down absorbents and then began unloading trailer. They found that the drum had been damaged when loading by the pallet that was placed next to it. The crew repacked the drum into a salvage drum and all absorbents used to clean up the material that was released was also disposed of properly. The trailer was then reloaded and set on there way. The event only took about an hour to complete.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-30T09:14:44+00:00

  • City: Bloomington
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: An Engineering crew was working on a track next to track 22 (containing several Marathon Petroleum tank cars) in the West Colton rail yard, when they noticed a smell of propane. It was reported and I was dispatched. The entire cut of tank cars was inspected and CBTX 787961 was found to be leaking from the sample line with a hydrate forming around the plug, the hydrate was rinse off the valve was in the closed position, I attempted to tighten the valve, but it was closed, product is leaking past the valve. As the plug was being removed the release increased and did not slow down. The plug feeling like it may be cross threaded. With no way to address the release a midland kit was applied to the tank car. Tank car is scheduled to be transferred.

  • Description: On October 11, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon jug of NALCO® 7330 was punctured by a nail and released approximately three (3) cups of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. A pH test was performed before remediation and a neutral reading was confirmed. The damaged pail was located and patched to prevent further release of product. Crews utilized rags to wipe down the impacted area to ensure cleaning. The damaged pail and all spent absorbents were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

The fire department showed up on scene and were able to place absorbent down to prevent any runoff. The response crew showed up on scene at 2045et. The crew unloaded the drums to gain access to the leaking container. 2200 the container was accessed and was placed into the Salvage Drum and all absorbents were added to the drum that were used during the clean up. 2245et the trailer was reloaded and secured for transport and job was completed.

Sealer was added to the threads and the plug was replaced. The residual product on top of the car was cleaned and neutralized.

item.title: Report E-2024100633
item.description:
Report E-2024100633

Identified by scraper @ 2024-10-29T09:23:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-26
  • City: INDIANAPOLIS
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 03:31 EST, XPO-BIN contacted ERTS to report a spill of about 15 gallons of Lead Battery Acid from a 3045lb battery. The battery was punctured by a forklift at XLX, spilling onto the trailer floor. Contractors arrived on site and confirmed approximately 10 gallons of Battery Acid released to a 14’ x 6’ area of trailer floor and 6’x6’ to dock floor due to forklift puncture. The contractors neutralized floor & trailer with Sodium Bicarbonate and containerized impacted absorbents, wood and plastic to a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
